page.title: Stereotypes of groups within the United States

rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you.
rev.diff:
Line 3: Line 3:
==Native Americans==
==Native Americans==
{{See also|Stereotypes of Native Americans}}
{{See also|Stereotypes of Native Americans}}
â   â
[[Image:Cleveland Indians logo.svg|left|thumb|The red-faced mascot of the [[Cleveland Indians]] baseball team, [[Chief Wahoo]].]]
  â
[[Image:Chiefnocahoma.png|left|thumb|The discontinued mascot of the [[Atlanta Braves]] baseball team, [[Chief Noc-A-Homa]].]]
 
Native Americans have been stereotyped by others in both a negative and positive sense. There has long been an admiration of Native Americans as fitting the archetype of the [[noble savage]] within European thought, stemming from a cultural sympathy grounded within the post-[[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] theory of [[primitivism]].<ref>Anthony Pagden, ''The Fall of the Natural Man: the American Indian and the origins of comparative ethnology.'' ''Cambridge Iberian and Latin American Studies.''(Cambridge University Press, 1982)</ref><ref>See Paul Hazard, ''The European Mind '' (Cleveland, Ohio: Meridian Books 1937, 1969): 13-14, and passim.</ref> These positive portrayals of Native Americans as being noble, peaceful people, who lived in harmony with nature and each other continue within modern culture, e.g. the 1990 film ''[[Dances with Wolves]]''.
Native Americans have been stereotyped by others in both a negative and positive sense. There has long been an admiration of Native Americans as fitting the archetype of the [[noble savage]] within European thought, stemming from a cultural sympathy grounded within the post-[[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] theory of [[primitivism]].<ref>Anthony Pagden, ''The Fall of the Natural Man: the American Indian and the origins of comparative ethnology.'' ''Cambridge Iberian and Latin American Studies.''(Cambridge University Press, 1982)</ref><ref>See Paul Hazard, ''The European Mind '' (Cleveland, Ohio: Meridian Books 1937, 1969): 13-14, and passim.</ref> These positive portrayals of Native Americans as being noble, peaceful people, who lived in harmony with nature and each other continue within modern culture, e.g. the 1990 film ''[[Dances with Wolves]]''.
